data.text: Frame Pump vs Mini Pump vs CO2 Pump for Short Bike Trips
for short touring trips/weekenders...frame pump, mini pump or CO2?
For all touring trips I take my Lezyne Micro Floor Pump. In fact, it stays on my bike all the time.
data.author: Jacquie Gaudet

data.text: That’s the one for me too, superbly built, exceptional quality and great performance!
data.author: Simon Dodding

data.text: Mini pump with a flip out foot pad. Have used Topeak Morphs before, and currently have the Lezyne Micro Floor Drive.
data.author: Jack Glantzberg

data.text: same on both pumps. The Topeak is easier to use IMO and a bit more compact.
data.author: Chris Zubak

data.text: the lezyne threaded Chuck is a little finicky to get used to, but it saved the day a week back on a group ride when a rider with Aero wheels and a short stem tube needed air.
data.author: Jack Glantzberg

data.text: Any pump is preferable to CO2. A cartridge is one shot. If screw up, you’re toast.
data.author: Ben Beardmore

data.text: Topeak Road Morph G on board for any and all riding. I carry tools and parts to fix just about anything...all the time.
data.author: Pedaling Pete

data.text: Classic style frame pumps are great for breaking your valves unless you're good with them. Mini floor pump with a short hose is much better. CO2 is either for club rides or for emergency re-seating of tubeless tires.
data.author: Braden Graham

data.text: Tubeless is the only way I roll these days
data.author: Michael D. Parsons

data.text: so what happens if you burp a tire or tear a sidewall?
data.author: RobertandTammy Fancher

data.text: while not pleasant you can ride on tubeless tires. I had a huge puncture in Faro, which would not seal, and simply rode 4 miles to a bike shop.
data.author: Michael D. Parsons

data.text: Mini pump.
data.author: Todd Ostler

data.text: Topeak Road Morph G can be used on Schroeder and Presta and the gauge gives definitive pressure readings you can count on. Small enough and easy to use. Carry a spare tube and a small tube repair kit. Repair flats as they come, but make it easy and use the spare tube to let the repair set.
data.author: Jonathan Harman

data.text: CO2 is good for racing, not so good everywhere else.
data.author: Erich Tornado

data.text: I stopped using a handpump years ago, then CO2 and now tubeless for the last 3 years Never going back.
data.author: Michael D. Parsons

data.text: I used CO2 for a while. I found I had to carry a ton of cartridges with me, and even then it wasn't reliable enough to leave the other pump at home. The only advantage I can see is speed, which is not an issue when touring. Also, CO2 makes tubeless tire sealant go hard and stop working.
data.author: Erich Tornado

data.text: Topeak Road Morph. Have used this pump for years.
data.author: Frosene Sacco

data.text: Zeffel HPX full length frame fit (I am retro, and I love being that way).
data.author: John Wasko

data.text: Mini pump is much more environmentally friendly than cartridges.
data.author: Wai Sing Lee

data.text: CO2, personally. Especially here in Florida, where filling your tubes by the side of the road in full sun is an exercise in waterboarding in your own sweat.
data.author: John Almond

data.text: Anything but a CO2 cartridge. If you have used (or not used them) them for a while, you know why!
data.author: Mike Schlacter

data.text: Topeak Road Morph G is the only pump ever needed
data.author: Andy Decker

data.text: Topeak Road Morph G it is!!!
data.author: RobertandTammy Fancher

data.text: The Blackburn flip mini is a great portable “floor” pump.
data.author: Terry Snell

data.text: Even on the road bike, I always take a pump as well as a CO² canister.
data.author: Stuart Patterson

data.text: Mini pump with hose. 1 or 100 day trip
data.author: Ivo Kovacevic
